content: The Justice Department was considering whether to bring a detained Somali pirate to the U.S., Kenya or Somalia to face charges after the harrowing rescue of a cargo ship's U.S. captain. The FBI was preparing a case Monday, one of three possible options in what to do with the captured pirate. Both piracy and hostage-taking carry life sentences under U.S. law. He could also be handed over to Kenyan authorities, where other pirates have been convicted in the past, or sent back to Somalia. Somali media were identifying the pirate as 16-year-old Mohamed Abdi, according to the Somali Justice Advocacy Center in St. Paul, Minn. But a Justice Department official told FOX News that authorities have been unable to nail down exactly how old the pirate is as other reports indicated he is as young as 14. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514840,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: The Justice Department was considering whether to bring a detained Somali pirate to the U.S., Kenya or Somalia to face charges after the harrowing rescue of a cargo ship's U.S. captain. The FBI was preparing a case Monday, one of three possible options in what to do with the captured pirate. Both piracy and hostage-taking carry life sentences under U.S. law. He could also be handed over to Kenyan authorities, where other pirates have been convicted in the past, or sent back to Somalia. Somali media were identifying the pirate as 16-year-old Mohamed Abdi, according to the Somali Justice Advocacy Center in St. Paul, Minn. But a Justice Department official told FOX News that authorities have been unable to nail down exactly how old the pirate is as other reports indicated he is as young as 14. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514840,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: The Justice Department was considering whether to bring a detained Somali pirate to the U.S., Kenya or Somalia to face charges after the harrowing rescue of a cargo ship's U.S. captain. The FBI was preparing a case Monday, one of three possible options in what to do with the captured pirate. Both piracy and hostage-taking carry life sentences under U.S. law. He could also be handed over to Kenyan authorities, where other pirates have been convicted in the past, or sent back to Somalia. Somali media were identifying the pirate as 16-year-old Mohamed Abdi, according to the Somali Justice Advocacy Center in St. Paul, Minn. But a Justice Department official told FOX News that authorities have been unable to nail down exactly how old the pirate is as other reports indicated he is as young as 14. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514840,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

There's no point in bringing him here. We can't even decide what to do about the people at GTMO. I'd send him back to Somalia and let him fend for himself. He's doing that anyway; he will likely join up with some other land-based armed group and meet his end there.

content: This is a fourteen year old kid. He's not a terrorist. He's a "sidekick" to a gang of robbers. Why is this bit about them being terrorists mindlessly repearted? Their criminals, no different than a bunch of bank robbers - We don't kill bank robbers in America, we sentence them to prison. If it's a kid, then taking out all the anger over 9/11 seems a bit over the top. Blaming him for Mogadishu, which took place before he was born, is over the top. Perhaps it's Right to try him as an adult. I will leave such decisions to the prosecutors who can better evaluate him then I can. Dave

content: The Justice Department was considering whether to bring a detained Somali pirate to the U.S., Kenya or Somalia to face charges after the harrowing rescue of a cargo ship's U.S. captain. The FBI was preparing a case Monday, one of three possible options in what to do with the captured pirate. Both piracy and hostage-taking carry life sentences under U.S. law. He could also be handed over to Kenyan authorities, where other pirates have been convicted in the past, or sent back to Somalia. Somali media were identifying the pirate as 16-year-old Mohamed Abdi, according to the Somali Justice Advocacy Center in St. Paul, Minn. But a Justice Department official told FOX News that authorities have been unable to nail down exactly how old the pirate is as other reports indicated he is as young as 14. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514840,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: This is a fourteen year old kid. He's not a terrorist. He's a "sidekick" to a gang of robbers. Why is this bit about them being terrorists mindlessly repearted? Their criminals, no different than a bunch of bank robbers - We don't kill bank robbers in America, we sentence them to prison. If it's a kid, then taking out all the anger over 9/11 seems a bit over the top. Blaming him for Mogadishu, which took place before he was born, is over the top. Perhaps it's Right to try him as an adult. I will leave such decisions to the prosecutors who can better evaluate him then I can. Dave
